pxs#

functions#

This skript contains all basic functions used to evaluate pxs x-ray diffraction data.

â€“ Further information â€“

udkm.pxs.functions.calc_qx_qz(omega_rad, theta_rad)[source]#

This function calculates the qx-qz coordinate in reciprocal space for a given incident and diffraction angle â€˜omega_radâ€™ and â€˜theta_radâ€™,respectively.

Parameters

  • omega_rad (0D array) â€“ the incident angle of x-ray beam in [rad]

  • theta_rad (1D array) â€“ the diffraction angle or angles of x-ray beam in [rad]

Returns

  • qx_val (1D array) â€“ in-plane reciprocal space coordinate in [1/Ang]

  • qz_val (1D array) â€“ out-off-plane reciprocal space coordinate in [1/Ang]

Example

>>> calc_qx_qz(0.492,0.492)[0] = 0.0
>>> calc_qx_qz(0.492,0.492)[1] = 3.85
udkm.pxs.functions.calc_theta_value(omega_rad, distance, pixel, centerpixel)[source]#

This function calculates the corresponding diffraction angle â€˜thetaâ€™ of a â€˜pixelâ€™ of the detector in respect to its â€˜centerpixelâ€™. The â€˜distanceâ€™ between sample and detector determines the angular space fraction covered by the pixel.

Parameters

  • omega_rad (0D array) â€“ the incident angle of x-ray beam in [rad]

  • distance (float) â€“ distance between sample and detector in [m]

  • pixel (1D array) â€“ pixel or pixels for which the theta angle should be calculated

  • centerpixel (integer) â€“ pixel where Bragg condition â€˜omegaâ€™ = â€˜thetaâ€™ is fulfilled

Returns

theta_rad â€“ theta angle of the pixel or pixels in [rad]

Return type

1D array

Example

>>> calc_theta_value(0.492, 0.700, 244, 244)[0] = 0.492
udkm.pxs.functions.gaussian_back_fit(center_start, sigma_start, amplitude_start, qz_axis, intensity)[source]#

This function returns the fit parameters for a gaussian with linear background model as a lm model object for the â€˜intensityâ€™ as function of â€˜qz_axisâ€™. The start values of â€˜slopeâ€™ and â€˜interceptâ€™ are set to zero by default.

center_start: float

start value for the center of gaussian

sigma_start: float

start value for the width of gaussian

amplitude_start: float

start value for the amplitude of gaussian

qz_axis: 1D array

part of interest of reciprocal space

intensity: 1D array

part of interest of the detector intensities

fit: lm model objekt

allows to get fit values (.values), the used data (.data), the initial fit (.init_fit) and the best fit (.best_fit) for the further analysis

>>> 3.855 = gaussian_back_fit(3.85, 0.05, 100, qz, intensity)['g_center']
udkm.pxs.functions.gaussian_fit(center_start, sigma_start, amplitude_start, qz_axis, intensity)[source]#

This function returns the fit parameters for a gaussian peak model as a lm model object for the â€˜intensityâ€™ as function of â€˜qz_axisâ€™.

center_start: float

start value for the center of gaussian

sigma_start: float

start value for the width of gaussian

amplitude_start: float

start value for the amplitude of gaussian

qz_axis: 1D array

part of interest of reciprocal space

intensity: 1D array

part of interest of the detector intensities

fit: lm model objekt

allows to get fit values (.values), the used data (.data), the initial fit (.init_fit) and the best fit (.best_fit) for the further analysis

>>> 3.855 = gaussian_back_fit(3.85, 0.05, 100, qz, intensity)['g_center']
udkm.pxs.functions.get_background(scan_rocking)[source]#

This function subtracts the scattering background from the averaged rocking curve before t0 and thereby extracts the intensity distribution associated with the Bragg peak. To avoid negative intensity after subtracting the background fit the minimum is set to zero.

Parameters

scan_rocking (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the raw and analysed measurement data. This function uses the keys: â€˜unique_delaysâ€™: measured different delays, â€˜qz_axisâ€™: relevant range in reciprocal space, â€˜intensity_rockâ€™: intensity for each delay and â€˜qz_axisâ€™ loop-wise averaged.

Returns

scan_rocking â€“ The function added the keys: â€˜intensity_peakâ€™: background-free time-dependent intensity of the Bragg peak, â€˜ref_fitâ€™: lm model object that contains the peak properties before excitation as reference for time-dependent fit.

Return type

dictionary

udkm.pxs.functions.get_export_parameter(params)[source]#

This function creates a dictionary that contains parameters for exporting the analysis results. This dictionary contains the key words: â€˜plot_titleâ€™: string that contains the measurement number, its date, time, temperature, fluence and material name to link plots to the measurement, â€˜save_pathâ€™: string for a folder structure of date and time to save figures and results and â€˜file_nameâ€™: string for suitable file names of exported results. Additionally, adjustable plot parameters are initialised by their default values.

Parameters

params (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains all parameters of the measurement from teh reference file. This function uses the keys: â€˜numberâ€™, â€˜identifierâ€™, â€˜dateâ€™, â€˜timeâ€™, â€˜temperatureâ€™, â€˜fluenceâ€™ and â€˜peakâ€™.

Returns

export â€“ The entrees of this dictionary are used to export and plot the analysed data. The adjustable keys and their initialised default values are: â€˜bool_refresh_dataâ€™ and â€˜raw_data_pathâ€™: should the raw data from the measurement folder are loaded (default: False), â€˜bool_plot_fitâ€™: should the fit of the rocking curve are plotted (default: False), â€˜delay_stepsâ€™: xtick step for first delay range, delay of axis break and xtick step for long delays (default: [10, 100, 200]), â€˜bool_plot_2D_rocking_semilogyâ€™: logarithmic or linear norm of transient rocking curves (default: True), â€˜bool_plot_1D_rocking_semilogyâ€™: logarithmic or linear norm of fitted rocking curve (default: False), â€˜intensity_range_2Dâ€™: lower and upper limit of plotted normed transient intensity (default: [0.01, 1]), â€˜intensity_range_1Dâ€™: lower and upper limit of plotted normed rocking curve (default: [-0.01, 1]).

Return type

dictionary

udkm.pxs.functions.get_peak_dynamics(scan_back, export)[source]#

This function uses the extracted intensity distribution along qz associated with the Bragg peak to determine its time-dependent position, width and amplitude using a fit and a center-of-mass analysis. Finally, the transient relative change in respect to the averaged value before excitation is determined and exportedto a folder â€˜exportedResultsâ€™. The key â€˜com_borderâ€™ of teh dictionary â€˜scan_backâ€™ provides the option to narrow the evaluted qz-range for the center-of-mass analysis. The key â€˜bool_plot_fitâ€™ of the dictionary â€˜exportâ€™ enables plotting the comparison of teh Bragg peak fit and the actual rocking curve.

Parameters

  • scan_back (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the time-dependent intensity distribution along qz associated with the Bragg peak. This function uses the keys: â€˜unique_delaysâ€™: measured different delays, â€˜qz_axisâ€™: relevant range along qz containing the Bragg peak, â€˜com_borderâ€™: lower and upper border along qz for center-of-mass evaluation (default: full â€˜qz_axisâ€™ range), â€˜intensity_peakâ€™: background- free time-dependent intensity of the Bragg peak, â€˜ref_fitâ€™: lm model object that contains the peak properties before excitation as reference for time-dependent fit, â€˜temperatureâ€™: temperature of the measurement in [K] and â€˜fluenceâ€™: excitation fluence in [mJ/cm2].

  • export (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the parameters to plot and export the calculated results. This function uses the keys: â€˜bool_plot_fitâ€™: whether or not the time-dependent fit of the rocking curve is plotted (default: False).

Returns

scan_back â€“ The function added the key: â€˜comâ€™: time-dependent position, â€˜stdâ€™: time-dependent width, â€˜integralâ€™: time-dependent amplitude, â€˜center_fitâ€™: time-dependent position, â€˜width_fitâ€™: time-dependent width, â€˜area_fitâ€™: time-dependent amplitude, â€˜transient_resultsâ€™: two-dimensional array that contains the relative change of the peak properties for both evaluations for each different measured delay.

Return type

dictionary

udkm.pxs.functions.get_rocking_rss(scan_raw, export)[source]#

This function calculates the intensity distribution along qz from an intensity as function of the detector pixel for a certain incident x-ray angle. The resulting loop-wise averaged rocking curve as function of the pump-probe delay is appended to the dictionary and saved in the respective folder structure. By the key â€˜qz_borderâ€™ of â€˜scan_rawâ€™ you can choose a certain range in reciprocal space that contains the relevant Bragg peak (default: full covered qz range).

Parameters

  • scan_raw (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the parameters of the measurement as well as the x-ray intensity as function of pump-probe delay and detector pixel. This function uses the keys: â€˜omge_radâ€™: incident x-ray angle in [rad], â€˜distanceâ€™: distance between sample and detector in [m], â€˜pixel_axisâ€™: array of the pixel numbers of the detector, â€˜centerpixelâ€™: pixel where incident equal to diffraction angle is fullfilled (default: 244), â€˜qz_borderâ€™: lower and upper border of teh relevant qz range (default: full covered qz range), â€˜delaysâ€™: all delays including several loops, â€˜unique_delaysâ€™: different measured delays and â€˜intensityâ€™: on reference diode voltage normalized intensity per non-excluded pixel and all delays and non-excluded loops.

  • export (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the parameters to plot and export the calculated results. This function uses the keys: â€˜save_pathâ€™: path to the folder to finally save the data and â€˜file_nameâ€™: name of teh saved data given by a combination of date and time of the measurement.

Returns

scan_raw â€“ The function added the keys: â€˜theta_axisâ€™: corresponding diffraction angles of the detector pixels in [rad] given by â€˜omega_radâ€™ and â€˜distanceâ€™, â€˜qx_axisâ€™: values of the detector pixels along qx given by â€˜theta_axisâ€™, â€˜qz_axisâ€™: values of the detector pixels along qz given by â€˜theta_axisâ€™ and limited by â€˜qz_borderâ€™, â€˜intensity_rockâ€™: loop-wise averaged intensity as function of â€˜unique_delaysâ€™ and the choosen range in qz â€˜qz_axisâ€™.

Return type

dictionary

udkm.pxs.functions.get_scan_parameter(ref_file, number)[source]#

This function writes the measurement parameters of the â€˜numberâ€™. measurement from the reference file â€˜ref_fileâ€™ into a dictionary and returns it. Necessary entrys of the reference file are: â€˜identifierâ€™: combination of date and time, â€˜dateâ€™: date of measurement, â€˜timeâ€™: time of measurement, â€˜temperatureâ€™: start temperature in [K], â€˜fluenceâ€™ - incident excitation fluence in [mJ/cm2], â€˜time_zeroâ€™: delay of pump-probe overlap in [ps], â€˜distanceâ€™: distance between sample and detector in [m].

Parameters

  • ref_file (str) â€“ File name of the reference file storing information about measurement.

  • number (int) â€“ The number of the measurement equivalent to row in the reference file.

Returns

scan_parameters â€“ Contains the parameters of the measurement. Always included keys are: â€˜identifierâ€™: combination of date and time,â€™dateâ€™: date of measurement, â€˜timeâ€™: time of measurement, â€˜temperatureâ€™: start temperature in [K], â€˜fluenceâ€™ - incident excitation fluence in [mJ/cm2], â€˜time_zeroâ€™: delay of pump-probe overlap in [ps], â€˜distanceâ€™: distance between sample and detector in [m]. Optinal keys are: â€˜powerâ€™: laser power in [mW], â€˜spot_size_xâ€™: FWHM of laser spot along x-direction in [mum], â€˜spot_size_yâ€™: FWHM of laser spot along y-direction in [mum], â€˜peakâ€™: name of material of measured Bragg peak, â€˜magnetic_fieldâ€™: applied magnetic field in [T], â€˜wavelengthâ€™: excitation wavelength in [nm], â€˜double_pulseâ€™: was it â€˜firstâ€™, â€˜secondâ€™ or â€˜bothâ€™ excitation pulses, â€˜z_posâ€™: z-position on the sample in [mm], â€˜y_posâ€™: y-position on the sample in [mm], â€˜pulse_lengthâ€™: length of the pump-pulse in [ps], â€˜colinear_excâ€™: wether or not pump and probe were collinear.

Return type

dictionary

Example

>>> get_scan_parameter('reference.txt', 1) = {'number': 1,
                                              'identifier': '20211123174703',
                                              'date': '20211123',
                                              'time': '183037',
                                              'temperature': 300,
                                              'fluence': 8.0,
                                              'distance': 0.7,
                                              'time_zero': 0.0,
                                              'power': 110,
                                              'spot_size_x': 960,
                                              'spot_size_y': 960,
                                              'double_pulse': first,
                                              'pulse_length': 0.1,
                                              'colinear_exc': no,
                                              'wavelength': 800,
                                              'peak': 'W',
                                              'magnetic_field': 0.0,
                                              'z_pos': -4.52,
                                              'y_pos': 2.25}
udkm.pxs.functions.plot_peak_fit(export, qz_axis, fit, ref_fit, delay)[source]#
This function generates a comparison of the rocking curve (intensity(qz)) with

the fit of the Bragg peak. The rocking curve and its fit at a certan delay is compared with the â€˜ref_fitâ€™ of the averaged rocking curve before t0.

export: dictionary

This dictionary contains the parameters to plot and export. This function uses the keys: â€˜bool_plot_1D_rocking_semilogyâ€™: whether the norm is logarithmic or linear, â€˜intensity_range_1Dâ€™: list of intensity min and max for plotting range, â€˜plot_titleâ€™: main measurmeent parameter as title of the figure, â€˜save_pathâ€™: location in the folder structure to save the figure.

qz_axis: 1D array

the relevant region in reciprocal space

fit: lm model objekt

allows to get fit values (.values), the used data (.data), the initial fit (.init_fit) and the best fit (.best_fit).

ref_fit: lm model objekt

allows to get fit values (.values), the used data (.data), the initial fit (.init_fit) and the best fit (.best_fit) for delays before exciation

delay: float

delay of the fitted rocking curve, used in the plot title

Return type

None.

udkm.pxs.functions.plot_rocking_overview(scan_rock, export)[source]#

This function generates an illustration of the transient loopwise-averaged intensity distribution along qz. The three-dimensional figure consists of two parts separated by an axes break to visualize both strain waves at small delays and heat transport for long delays.

Parameters

  • scan_rock (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the measurmeent parameters as well as the raw x-ray data and the calculated intensity distribution along qz. This function uses the keys: â€˜unique_delaysâ€™: measured delays, â€˜qz_axisâ€™: part of reciprocal space given by key â€˜qz_rangeâ€™, â€˜intensity_rockâ€™: loop-wise averaged intensity of transient rocking curves.

  • export (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the parameters to plot and export the calculated results in â€˜scan_rockâ€™. This function uses the keys: â€˜bool_plot_2D_rocking_semilogyâ€™: whether the norm is logarithmic or linear, â€˜intensity_range_2Dâ€™: list of intensity min and max for plotting range, â€˜delay_stepsâ€™: list of xtick step first part, delay of axis break and xtick step second part, â€˜plot_titleâ€™: main measurmeent parameter as title of the figure, â€˜save_pathâ€™: location in the folder structure to save the figure.

Return type

None.

udkm.pxs.functions.plot_transient_results(scan_results, export)[source]#

This function generates an illustration of the transient change of the Bragg peak properties by the fit and a center-of-mass analysis. The figure consists of three panels for teh transient relative change of the peak position along qz, its width and its amplitude. The delay axis consists of two parts separated by an axis break to visualize both strain waves at small delays and heat transport for long delays.

Parameters

  • scan_results (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the measurmeent parameters as well as the transient properties of the measured Bragg peak and its relative change. This function uses the keys: â€˜unique_delaysâ€™: measured delays and â€˜transient_resultsâ€™: two-dimensional array that contains the relative change of teh peak properties determined from a center-of-mass analysis and a fit.

  • export (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the parameters to plot and export the calculated results in â€˜scan_resultsâ€™. This function uses the keys: â€˜delay_stepsâ€™: list of xtick step first part, delay of axis break and xtick step second part, â€˜plot_titleâ€™: main measurmeent parameter as title of the figure and â€˜save_pathâ€™: location in the folder structure to save the figure.

Return type

None.

udkm.pxs.functions.read_data_rss(scan, export)[source]#

This function reads in the raw data (intensity per pixel and omega angle) and adds it to the dictionary â€˜scanâ€™. This dictionary contains the corresponding measurement parameters added by â€˜get_scan_parameterâ€™ and the evaluation parameters added in the main script. From the raw data the function exclude bad loops and pixels given by the keys â€˜bad_loopsâ€™ and â€˜bad_pixelsâ€™ of â€˜scanâ€™ and normalize the intensity on the crystal voltage using the key â€˜crystal_offsetâ€™. Scan with an intensity below â€˜crystal_thresholdâ€™ are excluded. By the keysof the dictionary â€˜export â€˜raw_data_pathâ€™ and â€˜bool_refresh_dataâ€™ you can refresh the data from the data path of the raw data during measurement.

Parameters

  • scan (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the parameters from the reference file. This function uses the keys: â€˜numberâ€™: row of refernece file, â€˜dateâ€™: date of measurement, â€˜timeâ€™: time of measurement, â€˜temperatureâ€™: temperature in [K], â€˜fluenceâ€™: excitation fluence in [mJ/cm2], â€˜crystal_offsetâ€™: offset of teh reference diode in [V], â€˜crystal_thresholdâ€™: minimum intensity not excluded in [V], â€˜bad_loopsâ€™: loops to excluded (default: []), â€˜bad_pixelsâ€™: pixels to exclude (default: []), â€˜time_zeroâ€™: delay of pump-probe overlap in [ps] (default: 0.0).

  • export (dictionary) â€“ This dictionary contains the parameters to plot and export the calculated results. This function uses the keys: â€˜bool_refresh_dataâ€™: whether or not the raw data should be updated during measurement (default: False), â€˜raw_data_pathâ€™: the corresponding path to the measurement folder (default: â€˜test/test2/test3/â€™), â€˜save_pathâ€™: path to the folder to finally save the data.

Returns

scan â€“ The function added the keys: â€˜pixel_axisâ€™: array of the pixel numbers of the detector, â€˜delaysâ€™: all delays including several loops, â€˜unique_delaysâ€™: different measured delays, â€˜intensityâ€™: on reference diode voltage normalized intensity per non-excluded pixel and all delays and non-excluded loops, â€˜omega_degâ€™: incident x-ray angle in [deg], â€˜omega_radâ€™: incident x-ray angle in [rad].

Return type

dictionary

rsm#

udkm.pxs.rsm.CalcPathList(sample_name, RSMQ_list, delta_theta, k)[source]#

This function creates a list of the qx-qz pixels resulting from the omega bins and the delta theta of the pixels. The four corners of the angle bin are transformed into qx-qz-space and form an area in reciprocal space.

Parameters

  • sample_name (string) â€“ name of the measured sample (named reference file)

  • RSMQ_list (2D numpy array) â€“ contains the intensity as function of the position in reciprocal space and the angles

  • delta_theta (float) â€“ describes the angle space due to the real space dimension of teh pixels [rad]

  • k (float) â€“ wave vector of the X-rays

Returns

path_list â€“ list of the arrays describing an area in reciprocal space

Return type

list

udkm.pxs.rsm.CalcQGridList(qzGrid, qxGrid, pathList, RSMQList)[source]#

This function creates a list of the QGrid, where each point of the QGrid is associated with an intensity as in the RSMQList.

Parameters

  • qzGrid (1D numpy array) â€“ contains the steps along qz

  • qxGrid (1D numpy array) â€“ contains the steps along qx

  • pathList (list) â€“ contains arrays describing the polygons in reciprocal space

  • RSMQList (2D numpy array) â€“ contains the intensity as function of the position in reciprocal space and the angles

Returns

QGridList â€“ relates every point in QGrid to information in RSMQList

Return type

2D numpy array

udkm.pxs.rsm.CalcRSMQList(sample_name, number, RSM_angle, unique_omega, distance, pixel_size, center_pixel, k, convergence_XRays)[source]#

This function calculates the transformation of teh Raw RSM to reciprocal space qx-qz. The detector pixels relative to the center pixel are associated with a different diffraction angle theta according to the pixel size and the sample-detector distance. The intensity at a pixel and an omega angle is normed by the area in angle space given by delta theta and convergence of the X-rays. After the transformation in qx-qz space the intensity density is normed by the Jacobian matrix of the transformation.

Parameters

  • sample_name (string) â€“ name of the measured sample (named reference file)

  • number (integer) â€“ line in the reference datafile wich corresponds to the measurement

  • RSM_angle (2D numpy array) â€“ contains the crystal normalized intensity for pixels and omega angles

  • unique_omega (1D numpy array) â€“ contains the measured omega angle steps

  • distance (float) â€“ distance between sample and detector [m]

  • pixel_size (float) â€“ dimension of the detector pixels in real space [m]

  • center_pixel (integer) â€“ input centerpixel: If it is positive this is the return value otherwise the calculation starts

  • k (float) â€“ wave vector of the X-rays

  • convergence_XRays (float) â€“ convergence angle of incident X-rays [rad]

Returns

  • RSMQ_list (array) â€“ contains the normed intensity distribution in q-space iterating the pixels for each unique omega resulting in len(unique_omega)*pixel num lines. Additionally, it contains angle informations and the jacobian matrix

  • delta_theta (float) â€“ describes the angle space due to the real space dimension of the pixels [rad]

udkm.pxs.rsm.CreateMapping(qzList, qxList, pathList, RSMQList)[source]#

The points of the recipracl grid which are in the polygon of the â€˜pathlistâ€™ are associated with the intensity from the Raw RSM corresponding to a pixel and an omega angle. THus every point in the QGrid gets an associated intensity.

Parameters

  • qzList (1D numpy array) â€“ contains all qz values for each qx value within the QGrid

  • qxList (1D numpy array) â€“ contains all qx values for each qz value within the QGrid

  • pathList (list) â€“ contains arrays describing the polygons in reciprocal space

  • RSMQList (2D numpy array) â€“ contains the intensity as function of the position in reciprocal space and the angles

Returns

QGridListTemp â€“ relates every point in QGrid to information in RSMQList

Return type

2D numpy array

udkm.pxs.rsm.GetLabel(sample_name, number)[source]#

This function returns the title for plotting the result, the saving path and saving name of the data and plots. Therfore the function â€˜ReadParameterâ€™ is used.

sample_name: string

name of the measured sample (named reference file)

number: integer

line in the reference datafile wich corresponds to the measurement

plot_title: string

contains the â€˜sampleNameâ€™, â€˜numberâ€™ of measurement, â€˜dateâ€™, â€˜timeâ€™, â€˜temperatureâ€™ and â€˜fluenceâ€™ of the choosen measurement

save_path: string

contains the â€˜dateâ€™ and â€˜timeâ€™ of the choosen measurement as an folder structure to define a saving path like the folder structure in the saved raw data

date_file_name: string

contains the â€˜dateâ€™ and â€˜timeâ€™ of the choosen measurement to give saved figures and data a usefull name

>>> '20181212/235959' = GetLabel('Dataset',0)[1]
>>> '20181212235959' = GetLabel('Dataset',0)[2]
udkm.pxs.rsm.LoadRSMTimeresolved(sample_name, number, crystal_offset, crystal_threshold, t0)[source]#

This function imports the raw RSMs from the measurement of the â€˜numberâ€™. line of the reference file of the sample â€˜sampleNameâ€™ for the different omega loops, delay loops and delays. The first dimension of the RSM denotes the detector pixels and the second the omega angles. All angle measurements with a photon number below â€˜crystalThresholdâ€™ + â€˜crystalOffsetâ€™ are replaced by the intensity of the last delay and the intensities are normed by the reduced crystal photon number. The RSMs for the different delays of the different loops are appended to a list of the structure â€˜fullRSMList[t][l][w]â€™. Here, w denotes the omega loops, l the delay loops and t the delays.

sample_name: string

name of the measured sample (named reference file)

number: integer

line in the reference datafile wich corresponds to the measurement

crystal_offset: float

denotes the voltage of the crystal without xray photons

crystal_threshold: float

denotes a threshold, all mangle measurements with voltage below become excluded

t0: float

denotes the temporal overlapp of pump and probe of the experiment [ps]

RSM_list: list

contains a list of RSMs with indizees: [omegaLoop][delayLoop][delay]

unique_omega: 1D array

contains the unique measured omgea angle values

unique_delays: 1D array

contains the unique measured pump-probe delays

omega_loops: integer

reterns the number of measured omega loops

delay_loops: integer

returns the number of measured delay loops

>>> LoadRSMTimeresolved('SRO',17,0.017514,crystal_threshold,1)[0]
>>> [[[array([[50.2,51.2],[0,0.5],[0.2,0.9]]),array([[50.2,51.2],[0.2,0.5],[0.6,1.4]])]]]
udkm.pxs.rsm.PlotList(sample_name, RSMQ_list, path_list)[source]#

This function plots the intensity of the Raw RSM in qx-qz-space distributed over the area calculated in the path list. The polygons map the reciprocal space.

sample_name: string

name of the measured sample (named reference file)

RSMQ_list: 2D numpy array

contains the intensity as function of the position in reciprocal space and the angles

path_listlist

last of the arrays describing an area in reciprocal space

udkm.pxs.rsm.PlotRSMRaw(sample_name, number, RSM_angle, unique_omega, log_plot)[source]#

This function plotted a raw reciprocal space map, i.e. intensity for omega angles and detector pixels, whereby the intensity is plotted logarithmic. This plot of the â€˜RSM_rawâ€™ can be saved in the data folder in â€˜Graphicsâ€™.

sample_name: string

name of the measured sample (named reference file)

number: integer

line in the reference datafile wich corresponds to the measurement

RSM_angle: 2D array

contains the intensities for the measured omega angles (X) and the detector pixels (Y)

unique_omega: 1D array

ontains the unique measured omgea angle values for the x-axis o fthe plot

log_plot: boolean

set wether the intensity is plotted logarithmic or not

>>> PlotRSMRaw('SRO',17,fullRSMList[0][0][0],np.array([50.2,51.2]),True)
>>> PlotRSMRaw('SRO',17,array([[50.2,51.2],[0,0.5],[0.2,0.9]]),np.array([50.2,51.2]),True)
udkm.pxs.rsm.PrepareRockingCurveFile(sampleName, number, qAxis)[source]#

udkm.pxs.rsm.calcCenterPixel(RSM, center_pixel)[source]#

This function calculates the centerpixel of the measurement, but only if no positive value is manuell given. The centerpixel is given by the pixel with the maximum intensity as sum for all omega angles.

Parameters

  • RSM (2D numpy array) â€“ containing a distorted RSM

  • center_pixel (integer) â€“ input centerpixel: If it is positive this is the return value otherwise the calculation starts

Returns

center_pixel â€“ the pixel with the maximum intensity of the RSMraw or the used defined value

Return type

integer

Example

>>> 1 = calcCenterPixel(array([[10,11],[1,2],[5,10],[3,4]]),-1)
udkm.pxs.rsm.calcQzQx(omega, theta, k)[source]#

Calculates the corresponding values qx and qz for a diffraction geometry of omega, theta and k with qz in out-of-plane direction. The calculation is based on equation (4) of Ultrafast reciprocal-space mapping with a convergent beam , 2013, Journal of Applied Crystallography, 46, 5, 1372-1377.

Parameters

  • omega (float) â€“ incident angle of the X-rays

  • theta (float) â€“ diffraction angle to the detector

  • k (float) â€“ wave vector of the X-rays

Returns

  • qz (float) â€“ the corrsponding qz coordinate in reciprocal space

  • qx (float) â€“ the corrsponding qx coordinate in reciprocal space

Example

>>> 6.34, 0 = calcQzQx(51,51,4.075)
udkm.pxs.rsm.createQGrid(unique_omega, pixels, qz_min, qz_max, qx_min, qx_max, qz_oversampling, qx_oversampling)[source]#

This function creates a grid in qx-qz space with bins along both directions. The gird along qz is given by the measured omega angles and the number of pixels determines the resolution along qx.

Parameters

  • unique_omega (1D numpy array) â€“ contains the measured omega angles

  • pixels (1D numpy array) â€“ contains the detector pixels

  • qz_min (float) â€“ describes the lower border of the analysed part of qx-qz space

  • qz_max (float) â€“ describes the upper border of the analysed part of qx-qz space

  • qx_min (float) â€“ describes the lower border of the analysed part of qx-qz space

  • qx_max (float) â€“ describes the upper border of the analysed part of qx-qz space

  • qz_oversampling (float) â€“ describes the additional resolution along qz

  • qx_oversampling (float) â€“ describes the additional resolution along qx

Returns

  • qz_grid (1D numpy array) â€“ contains the steps along qz

  • qx_grid (1D numpy array) â€“ contains the steps along qx

  • qz_bins (list) â€“ the boxes with left and right border to sort intensity

  • qx_bins (list) â€“ the boxes with left and right border to sort intensity

  • qz_delta (float) â€“ width of the bins along qz

  • qx_delta (float) â€“ width of the bins along qx

udkm.pxs.rsm.loadParameters(sampleName)[source]#

Load the Parameter list into the object. Oversamplingz is the factor that tells how many times the number of omega datapoints are used to sample the qz-Axis. Usually oversamplingx should be set to the same value as oversamplingz. 1/oversamplingx is the factor by which the qx axis stepnumber is multiplied

udkm.pxs.pxshelpers.calc_qx_qz(omega_rad, theta_rad)[source]#

This function calculates the qx-qz coordinate in reciprocal space for a given incident and diffraction angle â€˜omega_radâ€™ and â€˜theta_radâ€™,respectively.

Parameters

  • omega_rad (0D array) â€“ the incident angle of x-ray beam in [rad]

  • theta_rad (1D array) â€“ the diffraction angle or angles of x-ray beam in [rad]

Returns

  • qx_val (1D array) â€“ in-plane reciprocal space coordinate in [1/Ang]

  • qz_val (1D array) â€“ out-off-plane reciprocal space coordinate in [1/Ang]

Example

>>> calc_qx_qz(0.405,0.405)[1] = 0
>>> calc_qx_qz(0.405,0.405)[1] = 3.21
udkm.pxs.pxshelpers.calc_theta_value(omega_rad, distance, pixel, centerpixel)[source]#

This function calculates the corresponding diffraction angle â€˜thetaâ€™ of a â€˜pixelâ€™ of the detector in respect to its â€˜centerpixelâ€™. The â€˜distanceâ€™ between sample and detector determines the angular space fraction covered by the pixel.

Parameters

  • omega_rad (0D array) â€“ the incident angle of x-ray beam in [rad]

  • distance (float) â€“ distance between sample and detector in [m]

  • pixel (1D array) â€“ pixel or pixels for which the theta angle should be calculated

  • centerpixel (integer) â€“ pixel where Bragg condition â€˜omegaâ€™ = â€˜thetaâ€™ is fulfilled

Returns

theta_rad â€“ theta angle of the pixel or pixels in [rad]

Return type

1D array

Example

>>> calc_theta_value(0.405,0.666,244,244)[0] = 0.405

udkm.pxs.pxshelpers.get_fit_values(ref_file, number, intensity_peak, qz_roi, unique_delays, ref_fit, bool_plot)[source]#

This function returns the values of the fit parameters (centerFit,widthFit,areaFit) for every unique delay as result of a fit of the rocking curves in the region of intrest. There is the possibility to plot the results of the fits for every unique delay.

NameFile: string

name of the reference datafile

Number: integer

line in the reference datafile wich corresponds to the measurement

RockingCurves: 2D array

contains the averaged intensities for the unique measured delays(x) in dependency of qz(y1) and the angle theta(y2)

qzMin: float

the lower border of region of interest of the qzaxis

qzmax: float

the upper border of region of interest of the qzaxis

resultFitRef: lm model objekt

allows to get fit values (.values), the used data (.data), the initial fit (.init_fit) and the best fit (.best_fit) for the further analysis is the fit before t0

plotFitResults: boolean

if True the results of every fit for the unique delays are plotted with the function plotPeakFit

centerFit: 1D array

contains the center of the gasussian fit of the Bragg peak for every unique delay in consideration of the region of intrest

widthFit: 1D array

contains the width sigma of the gasussian fit of the Bragg peak for every unique delay in consideration of the region of intrest

areaFit: 1D array

contains the amplitude of the gasussian fit of the Bragg peak for every unique delay in consideration of the region of intrest

uniqueDelays: 1D array

contains the unique delays of measurement, part of delays without repetition

>>> [2.2,2.3,2.4,2.2,2.3,2.2] =
getMoments(RockingCurves,1.6,2.8)[0]

This function create a plot title, a saving path and a saving name for the â€˜numberâ€™. measurement of the â€˜ref_fileâ€™ based on the corresponding parameters of the measurement. Therefore this function uses the function â€˜read_paramâ€™.

  • ref_file (string) â€“ file name of the corresponding reference file in the folder â€˜ReferenceDataâ€™

  • number (integer) â€“ line in the reference datafile wich corresponds to the measurement

Returns

  • plot_title (string) â€“ contains the â€˜numberâ€™ of measurement, â€˜dateâ€™, â€˜timeâ€™, â€˜temperatureâ€™ and â€˜fluenceâ€™ of the choosen measurement

  • save_path (string) â€“ contains the â€˜dateâ€™ and â€˜timeâ€™ of the choosen measurement as an order structure to define a saving path like the order structure insaved the folder â€˜RawDataâ€™

  • file_name (string) â€“ contains the â€˜dateâ€™ and â€˜timeâ€™ of the choosen measurement to give saved plots and data a usefull name

udkm.pxs.pxshelpers.get_rocking_rss(ref_file, number, omega_rad, centerpixel, delays, intensity)[source]#

udkm.pxs.pxshelpers.plot_rocking_overview(ref_file, number, rocking, qz_range, delay_steps)[source]#

This function provides an overview plot of the transient â€˜rockingâ€™ curves of the â€˜numberâ€™. measurement in â€˜ref_fileâ€™ for a given â€˜qz_rangeâ€™ as two- dimensional map. The parameter â€˜delay_stepsâ€™ enables the adjustment of the focus of the plot with the steps for small delays, delay of the axis split and the delay steps in the second narrower part of teh plot for large delays. Finally, the plot is saved in teh corresponding â€˜RawDataâ€™ folder in a folder named â€˜exportedFiguresâ€™ using the function â€˜get_labelâ€™.

Parameters

  • ref_file (string) â€“ file name of the corresponding reference file in the folder â€˜ReferenceDataâ€™

  • number (integer) â€“ line in the reference datafile wich corresponds to the measurement

  • rocking (2D array) â€“ contains the averaged intensities for the unique measured delays(y1) in dependency of qz(x1) and theta(x2)

  • qz_range (list) â€“ lower and higher border of the region of intrest in reciprocal space in [1/Ang]

  • delay_steps (list) â€“ first: steps first part of plot, second: delay of axis break, third: steps second part of plot

Return type

None.

udkm.pxs.pxshelpers.read_data_rss(ref_file, number, bad_loops, bad_pixels, crystal_off, threshold, t_0, bool_refresh_data, data_path)[source]#

This function imports the x-ray intensity as function of the detector pixel for the â€˜numberâ€™. single angle measurement listed in â€˜ref_fileâ€™. The function returns the measurement angle, the delays in respect to temporal overlapp given by â€˜t_0â€™ and the normed intensity on the crystal voltage, where low intensity scans below â€˜thresholdâ€™, bad pixels and bad loops are excluded given by â€˜bad_loopsâ€™ and â€˜bad_pixelsâ€™, respectively. This function uses the functions â€˜get_labelâ€™ and â€˜read_paramâ€™

Parameters

  • ref_file (string) â€“ file name of the corresponding reference file in the folder â€˜ReferenceDataâ€™

  • number (integer) â€“ line in the reference datafile wich corresponds to the measurement

  • bad_loops (list) â€“ contain all bad loops that are excluded in further analysis

  • bad_pixels (list) â€“ contain bad pixels (0-487) that are excluded in further analysis

  • crystal_off (float) â€“ voltage at crystal without photons as reference for normalization

  • treshold (float) â€“ minimum of crystalvoltage corresponds to a minimum of photons per puls

  • t_0 (float) â€“ time when pump and probe arrives at the same time [ps]

Returns

  • omega_deg (0D array) â€“ incident angle of measurement in [deg]

  • omega_rad (0D array) â€“ incident angle of measurement in [rad]

  • delays (1D array) â€“ all measured delays with repetion for different loops in respect to â€˜t_0â€™

  • intensity (2D array) â€“ detected intensities for detectorpixel(x) and delays(y)

Example

>>> 23.2 = read_data_rss('Overview',0,[],[],0.021,0.1,0)[0]
>>> 0.405 = read_data_rss('Overview',0,[],[],0.021,0.1,0)[1]
>>> np.array([-1,0,0.5]) = read_data_rss('Overview',0,[],[],0.021,0.1,0)[2]
>>> np.array(([0,0.5,1,0.5,0],[0,0.5,1,0.5,0],[0,0.6,0.8,0.3,0])) = read_data_rss('Overview',0,[],[],0.021,0.1,0)[3]
udkm.pxs.pxshelpers.read_param(ref_file, number)[source]#

This function reads the reference data file â€˜ref_fileâ€™ and returns all parameters of the â€˜numberâ€™. measurement including â€˜dateâ€™ and â€˜timeâ€™ that are used for unique reference on the measurement.

Parameters

  • ref_file (string) â€“ file name of the corresponding reference file in the folder â€˜ReferenceDataâ€™

  • number (integer) â€“ line in the reference datafile wich corresponds to the measurement

Returns

  • date (string) â€“ date of the measurement

  • time (string) â€“ time of the measurement

  • temperature (float) â€“ temperature during the choosen measurement in [K]

  • fluence (float) â€“ fluence during the choosen measurement in [mJ/cm^2]

  • distance (float) â€“ distance between sample and detector for choosen measurement in [m]

>>>  0.666 = read_param('Overview',0)[4]
